Award.AwardTitle: CI-P: Toward Unified Tool Support for Linguistic Corpus Annotation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Development of the computer processing of language is a key scientific and technological capability that is funded by the NSF. In support of these efforts, thousands of texts, comprising hundreds of thousands of words, are hand-processed every year to provide data to train computer algorithms. This annotation is time-consuming, expensive, and difficult, and it is hampered by a long-standing problem: the lack of unified, specialized software tools to assist in annotation and annotation management. Researchers at MIT envision creating a new software infrastructure, called a Unified Annotation Workbench (UAW), that is an off-the-shelf solution to this problem. A UAW will significantly the effectiveness of every dollar spent on annotation. Importantly, a UAW will be useful not only to linguistic annotation community: it will also benefit many scientific and engineering fields that depend on people to annotation-like work. As a small selection, this includes human-computer interaction, cognitive science, cognitive psychology, sociology, psychiatry, and any field related to the digital humanities.

Computational linguistics and statistical natural language processing (NLP) are important areas of study, both scientifically and technologically. Advances in these fields are fed by a universal hunger for the analysis of language data for information processing tasks. Large annotated corpora are a key resource that enables these advances. But despite the widely-recognized importance of annotated corpora, the field has a major lack: there is no off-the-shelf, general, unified tool for performing text annotation. Faced with this lack, many language researchers create their own tools from scratch, at significant cost. These tools are usually hastily designed, not released for general use, not maintained, and often redundant with capabilities implemented by others. This leads to lost opportunities, as researchers forego projects that present too many difficulties in tool design; it reduces the ability of researchers to build upon and replicate other?s work, as a critical part of the infrastructure is not available; and this duplication of effort represents a significant waste of resources. In this infrastructure planning project, the MIT team will take three steps toward a Unified Annotation Workbench (UAW): a general, unified, off-the-shelf infrastructure to support corpus annotation. First, they will comprehensively review the state-of-the-art of annotation tools. Second, they will identify potential implementation technologies for a UAW and create software mockups. Third, they will organize a workshop to engage the annotation community as to the best form of a UAW.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to plan a series of actions to address a long-standing problem in field of computer processing of language (i.e., computational linguistics), namely, disorganized, redundant, and non-interoperable software support.  The PI performed a preliminary survey the current state of the software for the field, drawing a number of important conclusions and identifying important software tools and researchers responsible for them. The PI then organized a two-day workshop, held in Sunny Isles, Florida near his home institution of Florida Interational University, that convened 22 experts in this area from all across the world, including professors, researchers with doctorates, and research staff without doctorates.  The group of world experts comprised 14 from the U.S., and 9 from outside the U.S. (7 from Europe and 2 from Asia), including Australia, Germany, the United Kingdom, Greece, The Netherlands, and Japan.  The workshop participants identified 11 common problems with annotation software, 5 of which were deemed major. For each of the major problems, the participants identified numerous current projects, efforts, and organizations that could serve as potential partners and collaborators for tackling the problem.  Each major problem was also associated with specific imagined capabilities that the workshop participants thought would be the best approach to solving that problem. Finally, the workshop participants generated 17 specific recommendations for next steps, as well as a concrete plan to create a new technical working group, independent of NSF funding, to start tackling one of the recommendations. All of these items are covered in detail in the forthcoming technical report, which will be published in late 2015 as an MIT CSAIL Technical report titled "Report on the 2015 NSF Workshop on Unified Annotation Tooling"  The workshop and related materials are also described on a website that can be found at http://uat2015.cs.fiu.edu/
